title: California Approves Ban on Menthol Cigarettes
summary: New law makes it second state in nation to prohibit sales of Newports and other minty smokes over protest from tobacco companies. California has banned Newports and other menthol cigarettes, following a similar measure approved in Massachusetts last year.

title: Racial-Justice Demonstrators March on Washington
summary: On the 57th anniversary of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s "I Have a Dream" speech, protesters call on Senate to take action. Scores of demonstrators marched through Washington, D.C. Friday in a protest meant to hark back to the civil-rights struggles and accomplishments of the 1960s, renewing their push for policing overhauls after recent police killings of Black citizens and calling for a vote against President Trump in November. The group set off from the Lincoln Memorial to the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial about a half-mile away. The protest, organized by the Rev. Al Sharpton and his civil-rights organization, the National Action Network, is being held on the 57th anniversary of King's "I Have a Dream" speech from the Lincoln Memorial. Speakers called for the Republican-controlled Senate to take up legislation that has cleared the Democratic-run House: The George Floyd Justice in Policing Act, which would make it easier to prosecute police officers for misconduct, and a new version of the 1965 Voting Rights Act, which dictated federal oversight of state election law, a central provision that was struck down by the Supreme Court. George Floyd was killed in police custody in Minneapolis in May and Jacob Blake was shot in the back by police in Kenosha, Wis., both followed by protests, violence and looting.

title: AT&T Is Again Exploring a Deal for DirecTV
summary: Telephone giant in discussions with private-equity bidders for satellite-TV business wounded by shift to streaming services. AT&T Inc. is taking a fresh look at its DirecTV business, according to people familiar with the matter, exploring a deal for a service wounded by cord-cutting.

title: Cuomo Gets a Nursing Home Inspection
summary: A Justice Department probe will examine New York's Covid-19 deaths.. New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo has resisted inquiries by the press and his own Democratic Legislature into how his policy of returning Covid-19 patients to nursing homes contributed to an untold number of elderly deaths. But New Yorkers may finally get an honest accounting thanks to the Trump Justice Department.

title: An Evening Stroll With Black Lives Matter
summary: Protesters harass and threaten White House convention attendees on the streets of Washington, D.C.. Democrats seem to be figuring out that they made a political blunder by failing to condemn urban violence at their virtual convention last week. Then came the riots in Kenosha, Wis., in Minneapolis again, and elsewhere, and Joe Biden finally criticized the violence and looting in a video on Wednesday.

title: Shinzo Abe's Legacy
summary: Japan's longest-serving leader tried to make his country more normal.. Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said Friday he's resigning for health reasons, and it's his country's loss. His intentions were right even if he often struggled to overcome entrenched opposition to the reforms he knows Japan needs.

title: Kenosha Police Union Defends Officers Involved in Shooting of Jacob Blake
summary: Wisconsin city's mayor says he doesn't support protesters' calls to remove the police chief or county sheriff. KENOSHA, Wis.-The union representing Kenosha police defended the officers involved in Sunday's shooting of a Black man multiple times in the back, while the city's mayor said Friday that he wouldn't support protesters' calls to remove the police chief or county sheriff.

title: California Needs Ideas
summary: The state's worst blackout is the one on political debate, especially about its climate obsession.. No climate policy is available that would operate on a time scale relevant to California's hellish wildfire challenge, except throwing enough opaque particles into the atmosphere to cool the Earth.

title: New Coronavirus Cases in U.S. Rise for Fourth Straight Day
summary: Hurricane Laura adds to challenges some states face containing pandemic. Officials tried to contain the spread of the coronavirus amid natural disasters this week as California announced a new framework for reopening and as universities continued to contend with outbreaks.

title: Today's College Classroom Is a Therapy Session
summary: The tough guys are gone. Instructors are expected to foster 'safe,' 'nurturing,' 'antiracist' spaces.. Now retired after having taught 30 years in the English department at Northwestern University, I continue to receive announcements from the school. One not long ago carried the heading "Seven Honored with Teaching Award." I read it wondering if these models of superior teaching might in some way illuminate the question of whether the value of in-person education is worth the risk of coronavirus exposure.

title: Fatal Police Shooting of South African Teen Sparks Protests
summary: Demonstrators are demanding changes to how law enforcement operates in the country. JOHANNESBURG-The fatal police shooting of a South African teenager has sparked protests and demands for changes to how law enforcement operates in the country, which has among the highest levels of violent crime in the world and a large number of killings by police each year.

title: New Covid-19 Layoffs Make Job Reductions Permanent
summary: As companies brace for years of pandemic-related disruption, thousands of furloughed workers are told they won't be coming back. A new wave of layoffs is washing over the U.S. as several big companies reassess staffing plans and settle in for a long period of uncertainty.

title: Happy 100th to the American Mozart
summary: We talk often about race. Ever listened to the African-American jazz genius Charlie Parker?. Hearing alto saxophonist Charlie Parker for the first time, I was shocked that it was acoustic and not electric music. Parker played as though he were a comet in human form who had discovered chords from another world that happened to be made out of lightning, rather than notes.

title: Expected Surge of CLO Downgrades Slow to Arrive
summary: Reviews so far by ratings firms suggest the market is poised to avoid the same fate as subprime mortgage-backed securities in 2008. After the coronavirus pandemic shut many businesses this spring, the three major credit-ratings firms placed about 2,400 bonds tied to pools of corporate loans on review for possible downgrades. The potential wave has turned out to be more of a dribble.

title: RNC Ratings: Final Night Draws 23.8 Million Viewers
summary: Audience for fourth day of 2020 event was 26% smaller than in 2016, and 3.2% smaller than DNC's 2020 final night. About 23.8 million viewers tuned in to President Trump's prime-time convention speech Thursday night, according to Nielsen, a smaller audience than the one that watched former Vice President Joe Biden accept the Democratic Party nomination last week.

title: U.S. Colleges Continue to Grapple With Coronavirus Outbreaks
summary: Leaders at schools in Georgia, Texas and Iowa warn about the spread. Colleges nationwide continue to struggle with increasing coronavirus cases, the virus spreading seemingly unabated on some campuses in Georgia, Texas and Iowa.

title: Local Health Departments Rebuke CDC's Softened Covid-19 Testing Guidelines
summary: Groups representing departments nationwide urge agency to reverse move lightening recommendations for coronavirus testing of close contacts. Local health departments urged the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to rewrite its Covid-19 testing guidelines, pushing back against recent changes saying close contacts didn't necessarily need to get tested if they weren't showing symptoms.

title: Stocks Log Big Weekly Gains
summary: The Dow returned to positive territory for the year for the first time since February. The S&P 500 wrapped up its best week since early July, driven by improving economic data and signals from the Federal Reserve that the central bank plans to keep interest rates low for an extended period.

title: Tesla Bulls Bet Big Ahead of Stock Split
summary: A sharp rally in the auto maker's shares has unleashed options activity tied to further gains. A dizzying rally in Tesla Inc.'s shares has unleashed a burst of options activity tied to the stock jumping even higher.

title: U.K. Government Appeals to Workers to Come Back to the Office
summary: Officials are worried about the knock-on effect of offices remaining shut, with eateries and shops facing huge business declines. LONDON-All summer, the British government has been appealing for Britons to return to work, trying to coax white-collar workers out of their homes and back into their offices.

title: Trump, Biden and America
summary: Patriotism, prosperity and public safety are winning themes.. In his Thursday night acceptance speech at the Republican National Convention, President Donald Trump offered an unapologetic and forceful defense of America and the people responsible for its public safety. He also defended the liberty that is the source of American greatness. And he rejected the idea of continued lockdowns as a response to the coronavirus, arguing instead for reopening and revival. Don't be surprised if public opinion polls move in his direction.

title: U.S. Consumer Spending Rose More Slowly in July
summary: Wave of new coronavirus infections last month moderated stronger pace of prior two months. U.S. consumers boosted their spending in July, but more slowly than in prior months as new coronavirus infections rose and the expiration of enhanced unemployment checks loomed.

title: Bankrupt Hertz Sets Up Another Round of Executive Bonuses
summary: Between pre- and post-bankruptcy bonuses, key employees could rake in a total of $30 million. Hertz Global Holdings Inc. wants to hand out a further $14.6 million in bonuses to executives, months after the car-rental company shelled out $16.2 million in extra pay meant to keep executives from leaving as the Covid-19 pandemic upended the travel industry.

title: House Chairman Moves to Hold Pompeo in Contempt of Congress
summary: State Department refused to provide documents sought in July subpoena, sparking a likely House vote. House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Eliot Engel (D., N.Y.) has initiated contempt proceedings against Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, alleging the top U.S. diplomat has hindered a congressional inquiry into his alleged politicization of the department.

title: We Tested 50 Face Masks to Find the Best
summary: How does one find the best reusable, unisex, cloth face covering? Our panel of five editor-testers rated and ranked a huge variety of masks on style, breathability, fit and material.. KEYS, WALLET, face mask. In just a few short months, the cloth face covering-once a concept Americans only saw while overseas-has become an essential item, required in many public places. It's hard to think of an another accessory that so radically and rapidly became integral to our daily lives, except perhaps for the smartphone. "I would say this is one of the biggest short-term booms we've ever seen...from a wearable product," said Marshal Cohen, chief industry adviser at the NPD Group, a market research firm.

title: Noonan Misses on the Democratic Convention
summary: The reason Trump supporters aren't rising up is the same reason they can't wear a MAGA hat in public: fear of being verbally abused or physically assaulted.. Regarding Peggy Noonan's "The Democrats Miss the Meaning" (Declarations, Aug. 22): Ms. Noonan isn't seeing President Trump's supporters rise up in indignant defense after hearing former President Obama's "unprecedented" insulting remarks about him at the Democratic convention.

title: Has President Trump Strengthened the GOP?
summary: Gerald F. Seib gives way too much credit to Donald Trump for achieving the "new gospel of populism.". In "How Trump Has Changed the Republicans" (Review, Aug. 22), Gerald F. Seib gives way too much credit to Donald Trump for achieving the "new gospel of populism." Mr. Seib credits president Trump with a better understanding of the sentiments and mood of the populace, but in reality Mr. Trump has shown to have little real understanding of anything so profound. He reminds me of Chance, the simple-minded gardener Peter Sellers plays in the film "Being There," who gets world-wide recognition for saying what's on his mind without any understanding of its impact. Mr. Trump is manipulated by others into appointing people who will carry out their conservative agendas while feeding his desperate need for admiration.

title: The Hazard Is Bad Voter Lists, Not the USPS
summary: The real problem is not the U.S. Postal Service-it's the dirty (unedited) mailing lists for voter rolls on the county level.. Regarding your editorials "A Mail-Voting Redo in New Jersey" (Aug. 22) and "The Phony Post Office War" (Aug. 24): The real problem is not the U.S. Postal Service-it's the dirty (unedited) mailing lists for voter rolls on the county level. When I ran for the Virginia State House of Delegates as an independent in 1997, I rented the mailing list of voters in my home (Reston) precincts in order to send out campaign postcards. Much to my astonishment, I found nine voters living at my address when only my wife and I lived there. The other seven were the homeowners (living overseas as diplomats), our three children (who lived elsewhere) and the previous renters. We were the only local voters living at that address. Next door was a young couple, surprised to know that five voters lived in their home. The same was true up and down our block as I knocked on doors and canvassed for votes. Theoretically, I could have voted for myself nine times.

title: Some of the Wealthiest Colleges in the U.S. Are Raising Tuition This Year
summary: Cornell, Harvard and Yale are among schools with large endowments that are pressing ahead with price increases during the coronavirus pandemic. As the start of the fall semester approaches, at least 39 U.S. colleges and universities whose endowments are in the top 100 are raising tuition prices, according to a MarketWatch analysis. They include Cornell University, Harvard University, Stanford University and Yale University. The increases are underway despite the disruptions that the coronavirus pandemic is inflicting across campuses, from virtual classes to restricted student activities. "It seems ridiculous to keep paying the same amount for seems to be an inferior hybridized education," said Christian Baran, 21, who was a sophomore at Cornell University when it sent students home at the onset of the pandemic last spring. In light of the school's decision to move forward with a 3.6% tuition increase, he decided to enroll in community college for the fall semester and hopes to return to Cornell in the spring. "I don't think that it's worth it," he said.

title: Herbalife Nutrition Agrees to Pay $123 Million to Settle China Bribery Allegations
summary: The settlements with the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission resolve charges that the company falsified books and records. Herbalife Nutrition Ltd. on Friday agreed to pay $123 million to settle charges that it provided corrupt payments to government officials in China and falsified its books and records.

title: Seismic-Data Provider SAExploration Files for Bankruptcy
summary: Houston-based services provider to oil-and-gas industry has deal to swap debt for equity. Oil-services provider SAExploration Holdings Inc., which received millions in coronavirus aid from the federal government, filed for bankruptcy with plans to hand ownership of most of the business to lenders and bondholders as a way to deal with challenges facing the energy industry.

title: Christopher Nolan's 'Tenet' Makes a Global Bet on the Film Industry
summary: Resume Subscription. In Christopher Nolan's new thriller, "Tenet," the fate of humanity pivots on characters moving back and forth through time. It is an epic, brain-bending exploration of ideas the filmmaker has spent decades examining.

title: From 'Freezer Farms' to Jets, Logistics Operators Prepare for a Covid-19 Vaccine
summary: Shipping drugs safely from manufacturing plants to medical teams will be a high-wire act with risks at every stage. Logistics providers are building giant cold-storage facilities, or "freezer farms," and lining up equipment and transportation capacity as they gear up for the rapid delivery of millions of doses of potential coronavirus vaccines around the world.

title: For a Few Destinations, Tourism Is Doing Better Than Ever
summary: The big vacation is out. America is going camping (and boating and hiking and fishing) instead.. The pandemic pummeled tourist hubs across the country this summer as families shunned the usual vacation hot spots, canceling flights and scrapping plans for beach getaways. But for some rustic destinations within a day's drive of big U.S. cities, the coronavirus crisis unleashed a boom.

title: Chapter 9 Is the Best Bad Option for Chicago's Pensions
summary: Bankruptcy is inevitable. Putting it off only increases the pain for the city's residents and retirees.. Chicago's pension problems are nothing new. Analysts and observers have known for years that the Windy City's annual pension contributions were unsustainable. In 2016, the contribution for 2022 was projected to reach nearly $2 billion, 4.3 times what it was for 2014. Despite this gargantuan contribution, the pension plans' funded ratio was projected to plummet-from a poor 31% in 2015 to an alarmingly low 26% in 2021. I urged Chicago at the time to increase its annual contributions by enough to prevent the funded ratio from dropping below 31%. Doing so would still have left Chicago's pensions in worse shape than those of any major city in the U.S., but at least the hole wouldn't get deeper. Chicago's leaders did not embrace my recommendation.

title: One Step Ahead of the Woke Mob
summary: Amid successive global hysterias, says the novelist and exercise fanatic Lionel Shriver, 'satire can't keep up.'. Writers often exalt those who "speak truth to power," but few speak as fearlessly as the novelist Lionel Shriver. Donning a sombrero at an Australian literary event in 2016, she gave a speech demolishing the notion of "cultural appropriation," which condemns borrowing from or even describing other cultures. "The ultimate endpoint of keeping our mitts off experience that doesn't belong to us," she said, "is that there is no fiction."

title: Meteorites Are Art From Outer Space
summary: The newest collecting market involves some of the oldest objects on the planet.. One of the newest collecting markets deals in some of the oldest objects on the planet. Meteorites are chunks of metal and stone from outer-space objects that fall to Earth. People have collected them since the 18th century, but prices languished for most of the 20th century, according to James Hyslop, head of the Science and Natural History department at Christie's. He says that interest in meteorites rose dramatically after the 1993 movie "Jurassic Park," which created new demand for dinosaur fossils and other ancient collectibles. At a Christie's sale this month, "Deep Impact: Lunar and Rare Meteorites," more than one-third of the meteorites beat their high estimates. Earlier in August, Dallas-based Heritage Auctions got $162,500 for a 5-pound chunk of Mars that eventually landed on Earth.

title: With His TikTok Pursuit, Walmart CEO Seeks to Revamp Retailer Again
summary: Doug McMillon has spent heavily on e-commerce-now he wants retail giant to jump into social media. Doug McMillon has worked to remake Walmart Inc. since becoming its chief executive six years ago. He has all but stopped building new U.S. stores, spent roughly $20 billion on e-commerce startups and retreated from Brazil and other countries.

title: NBA Playoffs Will Resume Saturday After Deal on Voting Initiatives
summary: The league and its players' union struck a deal to restart the season-and turn NBA arenas into voting sites for November's election-after the Milwaukee Bucks' boycott. The NBA and its players said on Friday the league will resume the basketball playoffs on Saturday, part of a broader agreement in which team owners will work with local election officials to convert more arenas into voting sites for November's election.

title: What Happens When Covid-19 Disbands a Campus Club
summary: What dozens of students built at a weekly Super Smash Bros. tournament-and what they left behind. The large majority of colleges across the country are starting the fall semester with remote classes, with less than a quarter of schools attempting primarily in-person instruction. This has radically transformed the college experience, including the social fabric created by clubs and activities that give students a feeling of community and help them develop a sense of autonomy.

title: Photos of the Week
summary: Resume Subscription. The new coronavirus that infected Tricia Sales, left, in March still plagues her. The horse trainer and onetime cocktail server deals with dizziness and nausea. At times, she can't feel her hands and feet.

title: EU to Sanction Belarus Officials for Protest Crackdown
summary: Bloc cites violent repression of protests, rights violations under Lukashenko. BERLIN-European Union foreign ministers agreed to impose sanctions on senior Belarusian officials in response to what the EU called violent repression against peaceful protesters and opposition figures by the country's autocratic regime.

title: September Feels Like March, and It's Very, Very Sad
summary: A note from the most self-assured 30 days on the calendar. Hey everybody,

title: Japan's Shinzo Abe Leaves 'Abenomics' Project Unfinished
summary: Prime minister promised to remake economy, but country still falls below peers in productivity and ease of doing business. TOKYO-During Shinzo Abe's almost eight-year stretch as prime minister, Japan's economy had its longest run of post-World War II growth, unemployment fell to a quarter-century low and the main stock index doubled in value.

title: How's the CEO 'Stakeholder Pledge' Working Out?
summary: A year ago, 181 CEOs signed the Business Roundtable pledge to prioritize customers, employees, suppliers and their communities along with shareholders. Then a pandemic hit.. One year and a pandemic ago, a group of nearly 200 of America's most powerful executives vowed to employ a kinder, gentler way to measure business success.

title: From BTS to Cardi B: The Best Songs You Should Be Listening to Right Now
summary: WSJ.'s monthly roundup of new pop releases: everything that's grabbing our attention, making us think or getting us dancing. You can find this latest playlist and more on our new Spotify page. Listen to the full playlist on Spotify here.

title: Canada Data Point to Third-Quarter Rebound
summary: GDP fell 38.7% annualized in second quarter, close to expectations, while preliminary data point to record third-quarter gain. OTTAWA-Canadian economic output plunged by a record amount in the second quarter, fueled by pandemic-related restrictions on activity, while data indicated that a strong expansion is in the offing for the current quarter.

title: Carlyle Group's David Rubenstein on How the Pandemic Will Change the Rest of His Life
summary: The co-executive chairman of the private-equity giant talks leadership, regrets and why he now wants to give away his money faster. David Rubenstein has been ruminating about death lately. "Covid has made me realize my own mortality," says the 71-year-old billionaire co-executive chairman of the Carlyle Group Inc., a private-equity firm he co-founded in Washington in 1987. "You kind of say, 'How come 170,000 people have died and I haven't?'"

title: Trump Portrays Biden as 'Trojan Horse' in Emerging GOP Theme
summary: In playing down the coronavirus and playing up their law-and-order message, Republicans think they shifted the campaign trend lines this week. Among those making a surprise appearance at this week's Republican national convention: a Trojan horse.

title: NATO, Faced With Limited Options, Looks to Ease Greece-Turkey Tensions
summary: The latest flashpoint over maritime rights follows a string of Turkish actions that have exasperated allies. BRUSSELS-A growing dispute between NATO members Greece and Turkey is straining a military alliance that has in recent years been confounded by Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's increasingly assertive and antagonistic foreign policy.

title: Taiwan to Ease Limits on American Pork and Beef, Smoothing Path for Trade Talks
summary: U.S. officials have long regarded the restrictions as the main barrier to closer trade links with Taiwan. HONG KONG-Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen said she would ease restrictions on imports of U.S. beef and pork, clearing the biggest obstacle to free-trade talks with Washington.

title: Warren Buffett and the $300,000 Haircut
summary: There's a reason the Oracle of Omaha is an ultrabillionaire as he turns 90: He grasped the power of compounding at the age of 10. The sooner the rest of us fully understand it, the better off we'll be.. This Sunday, Warren Buffett turns 90.

title: MGM Resorts Lays Off 18,000 Workers
summary: Casino industry struggles to regain business after pandemic shutdowns. MGM Resorts International is laying off 18,000 furloughed workers in the U.S. as a global travel slowdown impedes the casino industry's recovery from the ongoing pandemic.

title: The Secrets of Elite College Admissions
summary: In the final 'shaping' of an incoming class, academic standards give way to other, more ambiguous factors. Last year, when high-school seniors applied to college, they never could have imagined the mess that a global pandemic would create for their first semester. But for students at the nation's best-known and most selective institutions, they also will never know just how close they may have come to not getting in at all.

title: How Coronavirus Overpowered the World Health Organization
summary: The WHO spent years honing its defenses but still had deep flaws. GENEVA-Sylvie Briand landed in China looking for answers. Nearly a month had passed since word of a mysterious pneumonia had emerged. It was now late January and the World Health Organization was struggling to learn more about it.

title: As Other Sports Protested Kenosha Shooting, Baseball Struggled to Respond
summary: While other leagues wiped out their entire daily slates, MLB took no preemptive measures, leaving each team to decide what to do. The response varied widely.. When the Milwaukee Bucks walked out on their playoff game Wednesday to protest the police shooting of Jacob Blake in Kenosha, Wis., they sparked a wave of activism by athletes rolled across sports. But Major League Baseball's response was inconsistent.

title: This Park Is My Office. Take Your Picnic Elsewhere.
summary: The urban workforce moves outside, encountering hazards like ants and sudden storms. Since he moved his office outside, Arash Azizi has dealt with rainouts, bird droppings and neck pain so bad that he is thinking about fashioning a harness like the ones used by ballpark vendors so he can keep his laptop screen at eye level.

title: 'Twilight of the Gods' Review: A Blood-Soaked Peace
summary: Ian W. Toll brings his three-volume history of the war in the Pacific to a close in a story of long-distance bombings and desperate island battles.. A tale-telling axiom holds that complex narratives-whether from a writer's quill, the pulpit or a Hollywood storyboard-are best broken into threes. From Sophocles to Coppola, the trilogy has thrived as a means to carve an enormous meal into manageable courses.

title: 'The Saddest Words' Review: William Faulkner in Black & White
summary: Novels like "Absalom, Absalom!" were haunted by the Civil War. So was the author.. I became an English professor because once, when I was 17, I opened a battered copy of William Faulkner's "Absalom, Absalom!" and read the first sentence over and over: "From a little after two oclock until almost sundown of the long still hot weary dead September afternoon they sat in what Miss Coldfield still called the office because her father had called it that," it begins, but then goes on in sinuous and majestic fashion. I thought of that moment recently as I read Michael Gorra's powerful book, "The Saddest Words: William Faulkner's Civil War," a work animated by an urgent, if irresolvable, question: Should we consider the novelist in our current period of racial reckoning through the lens of his sometimes repulsive racial attitudes, or should we study solely the fiction he created, fiction in which characters both black and white illuminate race relations in this country, fiction that portrays these relations with more nuance than almost any comparable work from the first half of the 20th century?

title: Race to Succeed Shinzo Abe in Japan Between Rival and Loyalists
summary: Former defense minister Shigeru Ishiba scores well in polls but lacks support among ruling-party insiders; Abe loyalists also in contention. TOKYO-Now that Shinzo Abe, Japan's longest-serving prime minister, has said he plans to resign, the big question is: Who will take his place? And can the world's third-largest economy manage the transition without upsetting the hard-won years of political and economic stability that Mr. Abe ushered in?

title: Five Best: Nick Fraser on Lost Lives
summary: From the author of 'Say What Happened: A Story of Documentaries.'. By Claude Lanzmann (2012)

title: Barry Sterling, Corporate Lawyer, Found Vocation in Wine
summary: With his wife, he founded Iron Horse Vineyards, known for bubbly brands. Barry Sterling was an established lawyer in 1959 when a trip to Paris, to celebrate his 30th birthday, changed everything. The Los Angeles-based Mr. Sterling was so charmed by French cuisine and culture that he began seeking a way to live there.

title: Military Service Launched Arnold Spielberg's Career in Digital Design
summary: World War II veteran, father of the film director, pioneered point-of-sale systems for retailing. World War II yanked Arnold Spielberg out of an early career as a small-town department-store manager and propelled him into the design of computers, including an early prototype for electronic point-of-sale systems.

title: A Good Life Doesn't Mean an Easy One
summary: A new study finds that for many, 'psychological richness' is more valuable than simple happiness. What makes a good life? Philosophers have offered two classic answers to the question, captured by different Greek words for happiness, hedonia and eudaimonia. A hedonic life is free from pain and full of everyday pleasure-calm, safe and serene. A eudaemonic life is a virtuous and purposeful one, full of meaning.

title: 'Three Rings' Review: The Long Walk Home
summary: Daniel Mendelsohn travels the long way around with writers from Homer to Sebald.. The 'Odyssey' of Homer is the Big Bang of Western literature, having sparked centuries of sequels, imitations, adaptations and commentaries. Every era has recognized its own upheavals in these strange yet familiar tales of the trauma of war, of wandering both voluntary and forced, of longing for home. Through the prism of the "Odyssey" one could write volumes about the ways in which books engender other books-about, so to speak, the reproductive life of storytelling. With "Three Rings," the writer Daniel Mendelsohn has launched just this sort of inquiry.

title: Political Books: War in the Spin Room
summary: The fight between the presidency and the press may be hotter than ever-but it isn't new.. The relationship between Donald Trump and the news media is a subject so complicated, so rife with ironies and half-truths, that it will take a century or more before anybody understands it. Mr. Trump loathes the press but seems to think about little else, and mainstream journalists feign objectivity even as they attribute every bad thing in the world to Mr. Trump.

title: 'Caste' Review: The High Cost of Feeling Superior
summary: Is social ranking color-coded in America? Do 'deplorables' belong to the same caste as the woke coastal elite?. Forest Whitaker is physically conspicuous and, most people would say, famous. In "Caste," Isabel Wilkerson narrates how the Oscar-winning actor, "a distinguished, middle-aged, African-American man," walked into a gourmet deli in Manhattan in 2013 for a quick bite to eat. The place was crowded, so "he turned to leave without making a purchase, as many customers might." An employee thought his behavior suspicious, blocked him at the door and frisked him in full public view.

title: Fiction: All We Can Know About Pain Except Why
summary: Yaa Gyasi's follow-up to 'Homegoing' is a powerful, wholly unsentimental novel about family love, loss, belonging and belief.. Yaa Gyasi's2016 debut, "Homegoing," was "ambitious" in the traditional sense of the word-a continent-straddling, generation-spanning historical novel that inhabits dozens of characters in its exploration of the ways the present is shaped by the crimes and collusions of the past. In comparison, Ms. Gyasi's "Transcendent Kingdom" (Knopf, 264 pages, $27.95), about the experiences of a Ghanaian-American family in Alabama, appears to be a slighter affair, narrower in its point of view and more personalized in its concerns.

title: 'The Bass Rock' Review: Sinister Tide
summary: A layered, quietly suspenseful novel reveals a family's most intimate secrets-and crimes.. Evie Wyld's 2013 novel "All the Birds, Singing" opened with a description of a savaged sheep that was so realistic that it seemed to perfume the air with blood. Ms. Wyld's new novel, "The Bass Rock," delivers a similarly immediate jolt, though this time the corpse is human and gruesomely packaged. "Resting in a rock pool was a black suitcase, bulging at the sides," the narrator recalls of her childhood discovery, and you can imagine the rest. A cloud of flies rises, "thick and heavy," along with a smell "so tall and so broad that you can't see over or around it." Hardly inviting. Indeed, in the hands of a more conventional writer, the effect would be repellent. But throughout Ms. Wyld's fiction, which transcends the category of either horror or crime, such visceral images, always sparingly employed, have a mesmerizing force that is instantly felt and eerily sustained. Whether the location is the Australian outback ("After the Fire, a Still Small Voice"), rural England and Australia ("All the Birds, Singing") or coastal Scotland ("The Bass Rock"), this author seizes her readers with the swift grace of the wild predators she often describes, then sets them down on terrain so richly imagined it seems to fill the senses. Here, for example, is a Scottish beach in winter: "A mix of black rock and pale cold sand . . . the top layer of sand skittering away, so that it looked like a giant bed sheet billowing." And later, a sea sketch: "The clouds had dropped down low and the sky turned a dark yellow, suggesting snow. . . . The water blackened, and quickened, sending sharp little waves with white at their blades towards the shore."

title: Mysteries: Corporate Scandal in the City of Light
summary: In Louise Penny's latest, Chief Inspector Armand Gamache of the Sûreté du Quebec travels to Paris on vacation but ends up investigating an attack on his godfather.. Armand Gamache, the veteran French-Canadian police inspector who stars in Louise Penny's long-running series of novels, received his moral education in the home of his scrupulously ethical godfather, the billionaire financier Stephen Horowitz. Even at 93, Stephen, who lives in Paris, has the reputation in business circles of "a sort of avenging angel." In "All the Devils Are Here" (Minotaur, 439 pages, $28.99), Ms. Penny's latest Gamache chronicle, the lawman visits his godfather during a family trip to the French capital-and sees that the old man has not relaxed his vigilance.

title: Why Colleges Won't Use Their Endowments to Offset Student Tuition and Fees
summary: As college students negotiate increased fees for often restricted experiences, some are asking why schools aren't stepping in to cover the costs. Many students who are being asked to cover fees for services they won't be able to use during the pandemic are confused as to why their universities can't use some of their endowments to cover the costs in the short term. WSJ Noted asked Liz Clark, vice president of policy and research at the National Association of College and University Business Officers, to explain.

title: 'The Book of Unconformities' Review: Of the Gaps in Deep Time
summary: Life is ﬁlled with unconformities, revealing holes in time that are also ﬁssures in feeling, knowledge and understanding.. Our lives, our histories and our prehistories are defined less by the seamless accumulation of everyday events than by jarring dislocations that seem to come out of nowhere. Cataclysms-think 9/11, or Covid-19-rupture time, leaving permanent scars that may be deeply personal or felt across entire communities.

title: Children's Books: A Wild Ride Into the Unknown
summary: Something special: An adventure story that's bursting with life and real feeling, and ends in a joyful call to goodness.. There is nothing so common as a children's book that incorporates fantastic elements such as portals, magic objects and talking animals. There's nothing so rare as a fantasy that elicits genuine wonder and that uses marvelous things to enrich a child's appreciation of ordinary ones. So Lev Grossman's novel "The Silver Arrow" (Little, Brown, 259 pages, $16.99) is something special. Here is an adventure story for 8- to 12-year-olds that's bursting with life and real feeling, told in a sparkling, informal style that parents will find effortless to read aloud.

title: Bet on Papa John's Shaq-Assisted Rebound
summary: Sales have benefited from the coronavirus, but turnaround efforts could mean years of upside. Good news for investors: The turnaround at Papa John's International is still baking.

title: Norwegian Air Is at the Mercy of the Elements
summary: The trans-Atlantic highflier said it would need more cash for the beginning of next year, but cannot easily sell its planes. Norwegian Air Shuttle 's survival isn't wholly in the company's hands anymore.

title: The Pandemic Is Making College Students Question the Price of Their Education
summary: Resume Subscription. When Mariah Stephenson received the bill for her fall semester at Towson University in Maryland, she did a double take. Even though fall sports have been suspended, she saw a $499 athletics fee on her statement.

title: Labor Day Grilling: This Spicy Side Dish Could Easily Be the Main Event
summary: There's more than one recipe for Rasta pasta, the jerk-spiced noodles from Jamaica by way of New York City. Here, 2 classic takes: the vegan version and its creamy cousin.. ON ZEREGA AVENUE in the Bronx, in the shadow of a DMV road-test site, two black drum-pan grills, spilling smoke and the smell of chargrilled meat into the air, signal the location of Kingston Food Truck. There's no seating, so customers line up along a chain-link fence, waiting to hear their names before taking their white bags to go, eating in their cars or heading elsewhere.

title: Hawaii Is No Longer Safe From Covid-19
summary: More than twice as many people have been infected in the past month as between March and late July. After largely succeeding in shielding itself for the first four months of the pandemic, Hawaii is being hit hard by Covid-19.

title: State Banks Are the Sin-Eaters of China's Economic Recovery
summary: Beijing's approach to financing the pandemic recovery has left the country's largest commercial lenders footing the bill. As China's recovery from the pandemic continues, the burden of the country's economic support measures is increasingly falling on its commercial banks.

title: Coca-Cola Plans Layoffs, Offers Buyouts to U.S. Staff
summary: Soda giant offers voluntary separation packages to about 4,000 staff in U.S. and Canada. Coca-Cola Co. said it planned to lay off some employees and offer voluntary separations, affecting thousands at the company, as it reorganizes its segments in a reorientation of beverage strategy.

title: Zynga's Not Played Out Just Yet
summary: Mobile-game maker's pandemic-fueled boost might be most likely to stick. Pandemic life has been largely good for videogame companies. Life should stay good for Zynga , as the rest of the world starts getting back to normal.

title: Regina King: What Justice Means to Me
summary: The TV kingpin, writer Nicole Krauss and Nia DaCosta are some of the luminaries weighing in on this month's topic: conviction. "Conviction is the most important quality for a creator because you've got to have the conviction that you're following something worth putting time and effort into. Most ideas worth telling are ideas that people are generally not going to think are great. You're "going against the grain. Look at a show like Sex and the City, a female-centered show about sexual issues that's extremely frank and R-rated, that's not going to be perceived as soft porn and is instead going to be funny. There were moments when I was looking at the first episodes wondering, Wow, how are people going to perceive this? When you're leading the charge, you have to have the greatest amount of conviction about an idea. Every project is starting from ground zero. They're all unique animals."

title: A Natural Balm for Children's Skin
summary: Giancarlo and Jane Keltner de Valle wanted to find a better product to treat their son's eczema. They ended up creating their own.. For Jane Keltner de Valle, style director at Architectural Digest, and her husband, architect and designer Giancarlo Valle, necessity was indeed the mother of invention. When their son, Roman, now 6, was a baby, he suffered from eczema, and the Valles were often shocked by the recommendations dermatologists gave them. "It was all packed with so many questionable ingredients," says Jane. They realized there was a gap in the children's skin-care market, so they decided to create Paloroma, a product line made with natural soothers like colloidal oatmeal, Roman chamomile extract and shea butter. Jane describes it as "pure and transparent in its ingredients, but not dumbed down in its design." It took the Valles some time to find the right lab that shared their commitment to avoiding parabens, phthalates, silicones, sulfates, dyes, petrolatum and scents. When they finally partnered with a company in Vermont, the biggest hurdle was fragrance, or rather, the lack of it. Even natural ingredients have smells, which compels brands to use scent as a masking agent. After a lot of trial and error, Paloroma is launching this fall with a trio of products: a cream, cleansing bar and wash. While many children's skin-care lines are baby-focused, the Valles want Paloroma to be transitional. "The products are something that kids can grow up with," Giancarlo explains. And offering approachable pricing ($12-$25) was also im-portant to them. "We bathe our children pretty much every day, so we know how much you're using these things," says Jane. "We didn't want parents to feel like they had to be precious with it and just use a drop." paloroma.com

title: Phil Swift of Infomercial Fame Buys Florida Home for $20 Million
summary: The man behind products like Flex Seal and Flex Paste bought the Gulf Stream home just a few days after it hit the market. Phil Swift, a boisterous entrepreneur who made his name appearing in infomercials for his company's waterproof adhesive bonding tools, has purchased a home in Gulf Stream, Fla., for $20 million.

title: The Florida Home of the Flex Seal Informercial Guy
summary: The 8,600-square-foot waterfront home of entrepreneur Phil Swift comes with an elevator, a gym and a wood-paneled office. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Cruise Ships Cautiously Resume Sailing in Europe After Deadly Outbreaks
summary: Ships are sailing below capacity and there are no buffets. To minimize the risk of infections, some operators say all passengers must be tested before boarding.. ROME-When one of the world's biggest cruise lines, MSC Cruises SA, resumed sailing in the Mediterranean earlier this month, it tested all crew members and guests for the new coronavirus before letting them aboard the 5,000-person ship.

title: Old Navy and Athleta Save Gap, Again
summary: Investors need to see evidence of a turnaround at Gap's perennially lagging brands, despite some good news. Gap Inc. had some exciting updates to share about its latest quarter, but some things looked all too familiar.

title: Democrats Lag Behind GOP in Data Race, Despite Making Progress
summary: Sophisticated data to persuade and turn out voters is even more important because the coronavirus pandemic has hampered in-person campaigning. With just over two months to the general election, Republicans are still leading in efforts to collect and harness voter data to spur turnout, even as Democrats narrow the gap after years of internal dissent.

title: SoftBank to Sell $14 Billion Stake in Telecom Unit
summary: Share sale adds to a string of asset sales meant to bolster SoftBank's debt-laden balance sheet. Billionaire Masayoshi Son's SoftBank Group Corp. said it would sell a $14 billion chunk of its Japanese mobile unit, adding to a string of asset sales aimed at bolstering the company's debt-laden balance sheet.

title: Chinese Covid-19 Vaccine Maker in Talks With Countries on Early Approval
summary: Executive at CanSino Biologics says company is discussing with several nations distributing vaccine before completion of final phase of clinical trials. A Chinese pharmaceutical maker is in talks with several countries to get emergency approval to use an experimental Covid-19 vaccine, developed with the Chinese military, before the completion of large-scale safety and effectiveness trials, according to a senior executive at the company.

title: Trump's White House Rally: Takeaways From the RNC's Final Night
summary: President says Joe Biden is a threat in unprecedented acceptance speech from South Lawn. WASHINGTON-President Trump accepted the Republican nomination at a White House event that resembled a campaign rally, using the trappings of the presidency to boost his chances of winning a second term while casting Joe Biden as a threat to the republic.

title: The Real China Reshoring Isn't What You Think
summary: Foreign brands need to retool for more Chinese spending at home. There has been lots of talk about shifting manufacturing away from China. But the most obvious reshoring that's happening now is actually being done by the Chinese themselves.

title: There'll Never Be Another Trump Rally Like That One
summary: Seventy minutes in front of America-and in front of the White House.. Trying to encapsulate President Trump's 70-minute speech to the Republican National Convention on Thursday calls to mind Monty Python's old gag about an "All-England Summarize Proust Competition." Mr. Trump touted accomplishments such as negotiating a new North American trade deal, appointing 300 federal judges, and killing "the world's No. 1 terrorist, by far, Qasem Soleimani."

title: A Resignation Salute From the Stock Market
summary: Japan equities fell sharply on reports that Prime Minister Shinzo Abe planned to resign. When a CEO resigns unexpectedly and the company's stock price drops, it's a badge of honor for the executive. But moving a single equity is one thing-a resignation that moves the entire market is quite another.

title: Will Chanel Buy in a Tough Neighborhood?
summary: French brand finally has a chance to own its London flagship store, just as shoppers have disappeared. The appeal of owning a luxury store on one of the world's most expensive shopping streets during a pandemic is about to be tested.

title: The Tour de France Was Obsessed With Germs Long Before the Pandemic
summary: The strangest edition of the world's most famous bike race begins on Saturday, amid rising coronavirus cases in France. Nice, France

title: Zero SR/S: This Whisper-Quiet Electric Motorcycle Won't Spook the Deer
summary: This sleek and impressive EV bike from a Silicon Valley brand lets you zip past wildlife nearly undetected, says Dan Neil, and enjoy more of nature's beauty.. IF A TESLA model S feels like a flying carpet, the 2020 Zero SR/S Premium electric motorcycle ($21,995, as tested) feels like the same carpet, only rolled up and straddled.

title: Chinese Bond Issuers Bypass U.S. Investors
summary: With plenty of dollars already in Asia, borrowers have less reason to look abroad. Chinese companies are borrowing less from U.S. bond buyers, as the deep pools of dollars held by investors in Asia means the region can be more self-reliant for hard-currency funding.

title: A Covid-19 Vaccine Problem: People Who Are Afraid to Get One
summary: Many Americans are reluctant or concerned about getting immunized against the coronavirus, including some at high risk of infection. Scientists and drugmakers are beginning efforts to overcome Americans' safety and other concerns about Covid-19 vaccines, while U.S. health authorities ready a campaign to encourage widespread uptake.

title: Why So Many Businesses Are Still Boarded Up Months After Unrest
summary: From New York to Seattle, some storefronts remain boarded up because of long waits for glass, fear of more tumult, and pandemic financial strains. Every morning when he unlocks the door to his New York City wine shop, the brown plywood covering one of its windows reminds Shermon Peters of the night nearly three months ago when looters smashed the glass and stole an expensive bottle of cognac.

title: Georgia Gets Cash Crush Befitting a Battleground
summary: GOP senator rakes in funds from outside groups to fight strong Democratic challenger; talk of payroll-tax cut raises Social Security as issue. GEORGIA SEN. DAVID PERDUE receives a gusher of outside money to help him fend off Democratic challenger Jon Ossoff. Since mid-July, the National Republican Senatorial Committee has spent nearly $5 million against Ossoff, a documentary filmmaker and former congressional candidate. Senate Leadership Fund, an outside group aligned with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, has as of Thursday spent more against Ossoff than any other Democratic Senate candidate-part of an announced $6.6 million "surge" of spending in the state. Another $13.5 million is on its way between September and Election Day.

title: U.K. Regulator Seeks to Expand Financial Crime Reporting Requirements
summary: The Financial Conduct Authority's proposal would require companies such as cryptocurrency exchanges to report suspected financial crimes. A U.K. regulator is proposing to expand an annual financial crime reporting requirement to a wider set of companies, including cryptocurrency exchanges and custodian wallet providers.

title: Data-Center Operators Holding Their Own During Pandemic
summary: Colocation facilities, where companies can base their own computer gear and connect to other services, continue to do well. Data-center providers that run warehouselike buildings where companies can base their computer operations are holding their own during the pandemic, industry analysts say.

title: With Virtual Conventions Over, Unconventional Campaign Revs Up
summary: Voters had a preview of each campaign's closing arguments: Law and order from President Trump; leadership out of crisis from Joe Biden.. The presidential contest is ramping up after the virtual conventions concluded with an at-times scathing address from President Trump, but the coronavirus pandemic guarantees the campaign trail will still be quieter than in years past.

title: Wall Street Looks for Inflation in All the Wrong Places
summary: Be wary of expert predictions of how Covid-19 and federal stimulus will affect the direction of consumer prices. The fate of your holdings rides on the outcome.. Investors grappling with the shape of the Covid-19 recovery have the same blind spot as they did after the financial crisis: They don't know how inflation works.

title: Hurricane Laura Exacts Lethal Toll, Causes Widespread Damage
summary: Strongest storm to make landfall in Louisiana in more than a century leaves tens of thousands without power; at least six died. LAKE CHARLES, La.-Hurricane Laura, the strongest storm to make landfall in Louisiana in more than a century, caused widespread power outages, severe flooding and left at least six people dead as it barreled through the state Thursday.

title: U.S. Announces Deal With Abbott Laboratories for Rapid Covid-19 Tests
summary: The test could be administered in a doctor's or school nurse's office and returns results in about 15 minutes. The Trump administration unveiled Thursday a $750 million deal to buy 150 million rapid Covid-19 tests from Abbott Laboratories , a move that would substantially expand the nation's capacity for rapid testing.

title: Spy Agency to Help Shield New Zealand's Exchange From Cyberattack
summary: Trading was halted for a fourth day on Friday by a denial of service attack that NZX said came from overseas. WELLINGTON, New Zealand-New Zealand activated its National Security System in response to a prolonged cyberattack that disrupted trading on the country's stock exchange this week.

title: Kyle Rittenhouse Faces New Charges in Deadly Kenosha Shooting
summary: National Guard members from three states deploying to Wisconsin city after protests over shooting of Jacob Blake. KENOSHA, Wis.-Prosecutors on Thursday charged the 17-year-old man accused of opening fire on protesters late Tuesday with killing two people, the latest in a string of fast-moving events touched off Sunday when video surfaced showing police repeatedly shooting a Black man in the back as he entered a car.

title: Derek Chauvin's Lawyers File Motion to Dismiss Charges in George Floyd's Death
summary: Former Minneapolis police officer knelt on Floyd's neck for about nine minutes. A lethal overdose of fentanyl killed George Floyd, not a knee on his neck, argued a lawyer for former Officer Derek Chauvin in a motion to dismiss the charges against his client filed Friday.

title: The GOP Tries to Make Its Case
summary: The Republican National Convention was strange, sometimes compelling.. It was a real insane-a-thon. It was genuinely moving. It didn't avoid big issues. It led with a lie. It was a success in that it will have pleased the base and done some degree of outreach to others.

title: Trump Promises to Heal Nation, Attacks Biden on Jobs and Crime
summary: President casts election as choice between extremist policies and the 'righteous heart of the American people'. WASHINGTON-President Trump accepted his party's presidential nomination Thursday, asking Americans to look past months of hardship wrought by compounding crises across the country and vowing to use a second term to mend public health, revive the economy and restore law and order to "Democrat-run cities throughout America."

title: The Trump Disruption
summary: His policy record is better than he and his opponents have made it sound.. When Donald Trump won the Presidency four years ago, half of America gnashed its teeth or cried and even supporters who cheered weren't sure what to expect. Four years later our verdict is that he has been better on policy than we feared but worse on personal behavior than we hoped. Whether Americans re-elect him depends on how they assess that political balance sheet.

title: U.S. Moves to Seize Cryptocurrency Accounts Linked to North Korean Heists
summary: In a first, officials say North Korean hackers hit a U.S.-based crypto company. WASHINGTON-U.S. authorities on Thursday moved to seize 280 cryptocurrency accounts they said were used by North Korean hackers who stole more than a quarter of a billion dollars from cryptocurrency companies around the world, including one in the U.S.

title: Fed Approves Shift on Inflation Goal, Ushering In Longer Era of Low Rates
summary: Chairman Jerome Powell says central bank has changed how it views trade-off between lower unemployment and higher inflation. The Federal Reserve approved a major shift in how it sets interest rates by dropping its longstanding practice of pre-emptively lifting them to head off higher inflation, a move likely to leave U.S. borrowing costs very low for a long time.

title: World Bank Halts Report Amid Concerns of Data Manipulation
summary: China, Azerbaijan, UAE and Saudi Arabia among nations whose data may have been inappropriately altered. The World Bank said it is halting publication of its flagship report on business competitiveness to investigate data irregularities.
